content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" emphasizes the need to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials, as stated by the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants for expanding opportunities for scientists and researchers and promoting underrepresented minorities in health professions. Additionally, support will be provided to institutions committed to workforce development in underrepresented communities. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities that demonstrate a commitment to health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including historically Black colleges and universities, Hispanic-serving health professions schools, Hispanic-serving institutions, and tribal colleges and universities. The eligible entities for grants include Hispanic-serving health professions schools, Hispanic-serving institutions, tribal colleges and universities, Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions, institutions with programs to recruit underrepresented minority health professionals, health professional associations, and institutions in communities with predominantly underrepresented minority populations. The grant eligibility criteria include being located in communities with predominantly underrepresented minority populations, forming partnerships to increase workforce diversity, and having at least 20% of enrolled participants as underrepresented minorities. Funds received must be used to expand, implement, or evaluate workforce diversity programs, including mental health initiatives. The grant funds must be used to implement or evaluate new workforce diversity programs, focusing on minority status in qualifications. Activities may include educational outreach, scholarships, postbaccalaureate programs, mentoring, and internship programs in hospitals. The grant funds are to be used for workforce diversity programs such as mentoring, internship programs, and leadership training in kindergarten through 12th grade and other health pipeline programs. Grantees must submit annual reports summarizing and evaluating their activities. The term "Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "Asian American and Native American Pacific Islander-serving institution" is defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020. SEC. 5. ELIMINATING DISPARITIES IN MATERNITY HEALTH OUTCOMES. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with various healthcare organizations, will conduct research to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. To address maternal health disparities, research will be conducted to understand determinants and distribution of care, health risks, and outcomes. Access to proven maternity care services for vulnerable populations will be expanded. A demonstration project in 8 selected states will compare interventions to reduce disparities and assess effectiveness. The demonstration project in 8 states will test various models to reduce maternal health disparities, ensuring representation of affected communities and evidence-based interventions. The demonstration project, starting in 8 states in 2015 and ending in 2019, aims to reduce maternal health disparities through evidence-based interventions. Grants may be provided for data collection, and states participating must report on their progress. The demonstration project, starting in 8 states in 2015 and ending in 2019, aims to reduce maternal health disparities through evidence-based interventions. States participating must report data to the Secretary on project outcomes, costs, quality of maternity care, and rationale for bundled payments. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress on the project results by December 31, 2020. The Health Disparities Education Program is outlined in Section 6. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about reducing racial and ethnic disparities. This program will include public awareness and outreach campaigns targeting the general public and the medical community. The program, established under subsection (a), will disseminate scientific evidence on racial and ethnic disparities in health care, including impacts related to age, disability, socioeconomic status, sex, gender identity, and sexual orientation. It will also share new research findings with health care providers and patients. The program aims to disseminate research findings on health disparities among racial and ethnic minorities, linguistic and cultural barriers in healthcare, and the importance of data collection on various demographics. It also includes educational initiatives for healthcare providers. The program includes specific educational initiatives for healthcare providers to address health and healthcare disparities. It also aims to assess the impact of these programs in raising awareness and providing information on available resources. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020.
